post_text: Wishing you a happy holiday season! We will be observing our holiday break December 21st through January 5th. School resumes on Monday, January 6th. The Office and building will be closed and all employees will be observing the closure. Students, enjoy your break and come back refreshed and ready to learn great things in the new year! Team Lumen

post_text: For the past 4 weeks, Mr. Peacock’s High School Basic Drawing class has been practicing drawing the features of the face (eyes, nose, ears, lips, and head). For their final project, each feature was drawn and arranged in the same proportions as a real face. The artwork is displayed on the Student Art Gallery wall in the Broadcast Center. Another example of Lumen's talented students!

post_text: Lumen students, Emma & Gracie Richardson, James Hilleshiem and Justin Owens, decorated an entry for the "Festival of Trees" dedicated to Herman Slaughter, a Lumen Kindergarten student who passed away last weekend from a tragic accident. The students interacted with Herman each week at the school's "Learn To" activities and were always brightened by his cheerful, sweet, happy personality. They were grateful to have had the opportunity to know him. You will be missed, Herman. View the tree on Aisle O-11 at the “Festival of Trees,” December 3rd-7th, held at the Mountain America Exposition Center, 9575 State Street in Sandy. Anyone interested in donating to a Go Fund Me campaign for the family can do so at this link: https://www.gofundme.com/f/memorial-funds-for-herman-slaughter

post_text: Lumen 6th graders celebrated “The Day of the Dead” or “Dia de los Muertos” by picking a loved one and giving a presentation on them for the class and their parents. Class members also painted their faces to look like sugar skulls. “Day of the Dead” is a Mexican holiday celebrated for loved ones no longer living. Tradition indicates the dead can return to visit their families on that day.
text: Lumen 6th graders celebrated “The Day of the Dead” or “Dia de los Muertos” by picking a loved one and giving a presentation on them for the class and their parents. Class members also painted their faces to look like sugar skulls. “Day of the Dead” is a Mexican holiday celebrated for loved ones no longer living. Tradition indicates the dead can return to visit their families on that day.

post_text: Mr. Peacock’s Basic Drawing class participated in a “Contour Drawing” assignment. Students had two options: draw the face of a model 1) using a single continuous line, or 2) using a blind contour (without seeing your paper). See their creative results!

post_text: Lumen High School students gathered and created 1,051 bracelets engraved with the words “Reach Out” to be given to Elementary students in Utah County. The bracelets are intended to remind students that they don’t need to “tough it out” if they are being bullied. Team Lumen...Making A Difference!
text: Lumen High School students gathered and created 1,051 bracelets engraved with the words “Reach Out” to be given to Elementary students in Utah County. The bracelets are intended to remind students that they don’t need to “tough it out” if they are being bullied. Team Lumen...Making A Difference!

post_text: Mrs. Barksdale's 8th grade US History class has been studying about the Judicial System and took a trip to Orem City Court, where they got a special lesson on proceedings from Judge Reed Parkin. After their time with him and taking a tour of the Court Offices, they sat in Court watching him adjudicate cases. Afterward, they walked over to the Orem City Library and looked at the beautiful stained glass windows that Mrs. Barksdale's father-in-law designed and painted.
text: Mrs. Barksdale's 8th grade US History class has been studying about the Judicial System and took a trip to Orem City Court, where they got a special lesson on proceedings from Judge Reed Parkin. post_text: Ms. Barksdale's Social Science class is learning about Topaz, the internment camp that incarcerated Japanese people during World War II. Students were given chopsticks and challenged to learn how to use them. Watch two students' experiences below.

post_text: Ms. Robertson's 7th Grade Language Arts Class hiked to Stewart Falls after reading their first novel, "Elijah of Buxton," the story of the first black child born free in Canada. Harriet Tubman took the runaways through the Appalachian Mountains. She followed the stars when it was clear and navigated with her vast knowledge of nature. The hike was a great way to tie in all the concepts and enjoy nature!
text: Ms. Robertson's 7th Grade Language Arts Class hiked to Stewart Falls after reading their first novel, "Elijah of Buxton," the story of the first black child born free in Canada. The hike was a great way to tie in all the concepts and enjoy nature!

Mr. Peacock's Basic Drawing class created chalk drawings of their interpretation of the theme "Heroes Around Us" at the first annual CHALK THE SIDEWALK over the past 3 days. Families, friends, classmates and staff were able to view the display and enjoy the artwork of our talented students. Students and family members will be voting to determine which one of the artwork displays best represents the theme, and the winner will receive a surprise in class on Tuesday!
All of our talented students are winners!
Join Team Lumen!

post_text: Ms. Graham's class read the book "My Side of the Mountain" to learn why people move and traits necessary to survive. They talked about Lewis and Clark traveling with Mountain Men as they moved throughout American History, and they enjoyed a visit from "real" Mountain Men!

post_text:
Did you know researchers have found that participants learn five times more material in online learning courses using multimedia content than in traditional face-to-face courses?

Because online courses give students full control over their own learning, students are able to work at their own speed. Generally, students work faster than they would do otherwise and take in more information. They are able to move faster through areas of the course they feel comfortable with, but slower through those that they need a little more time on.
#lumenscholar #lumenscholarinstitute #onlinecharterk12 #onlinek12

post_text: Lumen's 8th grade Science students did an experiment to show that heat increases chemical reaction rates. They heated and cooled solutions of baking soda and calcium chloride, then compared which one reached fastest. The heated one won hands down! #lumenscholar #lsi #lumenscholarinstitute #scienceexperiement #8thgradescience

post_text:
On September 15th, National Online Learning Day recognized the advantages and vast potential of online learning. It also honors the accomplishments of online students everywhere. Online learning offers valuable resources to parents, too. The ability to check in with teachers and assist their child remotely heightens the educational experience.

The goal of online learning at Lumen Scholar Institute is to cultivate blended and online learning and recognize the student possibilities available with this type of education. We are so grateful that you are a part of the Lumen Scholar Institute online learning adventure.
